Class HumanGame

  • java.lang.Object
    • HumanGame
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ComputerGame

    public class HumanGame
extends java.lang.Object
    Version:
    5/11/21 A human game is a game between two human users. It can input moves into the board, tell if a move is a winning move, and tell when the move is valid or not. It also keeps track of played moves by putting Move objects onto a stack called playedMoves. When someone takes back a move, the Move object will be removed and put onto another stack, called takenBackMoves. The game will end when it is a stalemate or when someone plays a winning move (one that connects 4). It will keep track of it is a stalemate by keeping track of how many turns there are. If there are 42 and nobody has won yet, it is a draw/stalemate. People cannot take their moves back once the game is over.
    Author:
    Claire Wang

      Creates a human game with an empty board

    • Constructor Detail

      • HumanGame

        public HumanGame()
        Creates a human game with an empty board

    • Method Detail

      • inputMove

        public Move inputMove(int col)
        Parameters:
        col - tells which column the token will go into. inputMove will have to calculate the row number as well
        Returns:
        A move object of the current move, or null if it is not valid. Inputs a move by setting an entry in the array to whoever's turn it is. Col is the column number it will be at, and the row number will be calculated based on how full the column is. Also creates a new Move object to be put onto the playedMoves stack. Switches the turn of the player. Adds 1 to turns so if it reaches 42, the game is a stalemate

      • goBack

        public Move goBack()
        When the user presses the back button, this method will be called. The previous move will be removed from the playedMoves and added to the takenBackMoves stack. The board will also remove the previous move. Sets the turn to whichever player's move was taken back.
        Returns:
        the Move that was taken back. Returns null if there are no more moves to take back.

      • goForward

        public Move goForward()
        When the user presses the forward button, this method will be called. The move that was just taken back will be played again on the board. The move will also be added back to the playedMoves stack and removed from the takenBackMoves stack.
        Returns:
        the Move that was just added back to the board. Returns null if no moves have been taken back.

      • isValid

        public boolean isValid(int col)
        Parameters:
        col - is the column number
        Returns:
        false if the column is completely full, true if the column still has space left

      • isWin

        public boolean isWin(int player,
                     int row,
                     int col)
        this method will be called before a move is entered.
        Parameters:
        player - is the number telling which player's token it is
        col - is the column number that the token goes in
        row - is the row number that the token goes in
        Returns:
        true if putting the token there is a win, false if not

      • getBoard

        public int[][] getBoard()
        Returns:
        the board

      • isPlayer1Turn

        public boolean isPlayer1Turn()
        Returns:
        whether it is player1's turn

      • setBoard

        public void setBoard(int[][] b)
        Parameters:
        b - is the new board sets the current board to b. For testing purposes.

      • setTurn

        public void setTurn(int player)
        Parameters:
        player - is the player who will be inputting the token. If player is 1, it means it is player 1's turn. This is used for testing purposes.

      • isStalemate

        public boolean isStalemate()
        Returns:
        if the game is a stalemate (every column is full and the players cannot change the game anymore). The variable turns is updated everytime a player makes a move, takes back a move, or goes forward. It will equal 42 once the entire board is full/ if it is a stalemate.

      • getBackStack

        public java.util.Stack<Move> getBackStack()
        Returns:
        the takenBackMoves stack Used for testing purposes

      • getPlayedMovesStack

        public java.util.Stack<Move> getPlayedMovesStack()
        Returns:
        the playedMoves stack. Used for testing purposes

      • getTurns

        public int getTurns()
        Returns:
        turns. If turns = 1, it is player 1's turn. If it is 2, it is player 2's turn.
